title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — Hersey Hawkins returned to Philadelphia not for a reunion, but for a demolition. In a stunning, career-defining performance, the Seattle SuperSonics guard laid waste to his former team, pouring in 44 points to lead the Sonics to a dominant 118-94 road victory over the 76ers in 1997.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Hawkins’ night. He orchestrated a clinic in offensive efficiency, a one-man hurricane that the Sixers had no answer for. His 44-point outburst was a masterclass in scoring from all levels, leaving a trail of frustrated defenders in his wake. The Philadelphia faithful, who once cheered for him, could only watch in a mixture of awe and horror as he systematically dismantled their team.

While Shawn Kemp provided his usual formidable presence with 12 points and a game-high 14 rebounds, and Gary Payton directed the offense with 13 assists, this night belonged solely to Hawkins. His historic scoring tally was the engine of the Seattle attack, turning what could have been a competitive game into a lopsided affair by halftime.

The 76ers, led by a valiant 27-point effort from Jerry Stackhouse and 20 from Derrick Coleman, simply could not keep pace with the singular force wearing a Sonics jersey. Every answer they had was met with another barrage from Hawkins.

In the end, the scoreboard read 118-94, but the story was singular. On a night in Philadelphia, Hersey Hawkins didn't just play a basketball game; he authored a personal legend, delivering a performance for the ages that his former team and the league will not soon forget.
